review_content: I have been a fan of the Rain-X blades for a while, so when I saw the premium 2-in-1 (blades coated with Rain-X formula), I bought a set (24"+20") for my BMW X5 and another set (24"+18") for my Kia Soul. To be more specific, it wipes clean on the way up, but leaves a very distracting smudge on the way down.  It didn't matter that I used it in the rain or with washer fluid - even after I wiped down the blade, it smears the water right across the middle of the windshield.  Overall, I liked the non-Rain-X coated blades much better.  I replaced the driver side blades on both cars with non 2-in-1 blades because it was starting to become a driving hazard and they are spotless clean.  They took a good product, made a bad enhancement, and charging more for it.  My suggestion - save your money and go with the non 2-in-1 and just use the original Rain-X formula if you want water repellant.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2017
review_content: I've had these on my car for about a month now, but have only seen rain a handful of times so far. Already though, I've noticed to major flaws and will therefore be going back to the Bosch Icon wipers. The first may have resulted from user error, but the failure the ensued should not even be possible with a wiper. The blade completely separated from the connector while I was driving. Luckily I was in a place where I could pull over and replace it, but had that happened on the highway it would have been catastrophic. A few days later, the rubber portion of the blade that removes the water began to slide out mid-drive. I used my wipers sparingly in order to avoid losing it entirely, and was able to push it back into place once I arrived at work. It was clear that it had not been glued in place and was simply slid into the track and left to hopefully stay put. When they weren't falling apart they worked fine, but I wouldn't recommend wasting your money on these. Spend the couple extra dollars and get the Bosch Icon wipers, they have worked for me as long as I've used them and I regret giving the Rain-X blades a try. I'll be purchasing them soon and tossing the Rain-X.

author: Amadeus B. Klein
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2015
review_content: Ok, as far as wiper wiper blades go these are pretty expensive but they claim to add rain x when they wipe so maybe not too pricey?** Update 5/22/16Well, I just ordered replacement blades finally. They started streaking on me.  So the life on my Honda Odyssey is about 5.5 months...  Honestly not too bad for the price.  I actually reordered these again since they worked so well.  About 2 sets of wiper blades a year is a pretty decent deal to me...** Update 4/14/16Ok here we are 5 months on since I purchased these for the van...  And I am honestly surprised to report that they are still working without issues..  they survived snow, ice, and rain.  All Without issues.  I have noticed that the "RainX" feature has faded pretty much completely but they still function as standard wiper blades without an issue  The RainX lasts about 3 months-ish...But at the 5 month mark I am no longer worried about price for value.  I usually feel the need to replace wipers every 3 months as they begin to streak or worse, but at 5 months they perform almost as good as new.  I would Absolutely recommend these if you have a Honda Odyssey (I have no clue how it works on other cars).  I have revised my rating to 5 stars, and I am in shock about that...** I'm really not sure how effective they are at doing the water repellency thing but they do add a bit of the water shedding to the glass since the rain does bead up and run off a bit more than it used to. I do question how long that will last though since traditional rain x only lasts a few weeks...The main reason I tried these was to attempt to  cure the bane of my wiper purchasing;  The need to find a wiper than not only does well in rain sleet and snow but also makes contact with the entire windshield.  I have purchased probably 8 sets of blades for my Honda Odyssey  and every single "beam style" blade I have purchased has missed the edges of the window (Where it curves around).  Happily these seem to actually touch the entire window.  They have mostly eliminated streaking and the "missing" portions when running the wipers.  I prefer the beam type as they seem to streak less and do way better in ice and snow than the traditional framework style blades.I think these are solid wipers and I would recommend them but can't in good conscience give it 5 stars since I don't know how long the water repellency will last.I will update this review and possibly adjust the rating once I've used them for more than a week.Just my thoughts,AK

author: T. Clark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2019
review_content: On the internet there are posts that say no aftermarket wiper blades work with the Tesla Model 3. This is incorrect. These blades (Rain-X Latitude Water Repellancy) are confirmed to work. Note that the sizes that work are 26‚Äù and 19‚Äù, respectively.1) Go to the Service menu on your 3 from within the car (not the phone app). Enable the top option, wiper service mode.2) Lift each wiper arm up off the windshield an inch or two and push the button facing away from the windshield about 2" from where the wiper blade attaches and pivots. Slide the OEM wiper blade towards the wiper arm's pivot point (to the left side of the car) and remove.3) For these Rain-X blades follow the instructions in the package for "narrow PTB" (pinch tab button). You'll remove two plastic pieces from it to get it set up.4) Slide it on per the instructions. Note that part of the mounting piece slides on top of the car's wiper arm (away from the windshield), so it won't look exactly like how the OEM one went on! I've highlighted this piece with arrows in the attached screenshot from Rain-X's own video. As the instructions say the tab on the mount will click into place where the OEM button popped through.5) ...6) Profit.It also mounts fine on older J bend designs, of course, which don't require pieces to be removed from the mount. For those make sure that you pull the blade all the way to the right of the car, towards the J bend. You'll know you pulled it far enough when it clicks a little, then you'll be able to secure the flap door at the end that locks it on. If not pulled far enough out then that door won't close positively and the wiper blade will not be safely mounted.
